thread.title: Make this iconic hotel your Maine squeeze this winter
thread.title_full: Make this iconic hotel your Maine squeeze this winter | New York Post

author: Chris Bunting
title: Make this iconic hotel your Maine squeeze this winter
text:
“Hey guys, it’s wintertime — let’s go to Maine!” said no one of sound mind ever.
Well, let us be the first.
And no, that’s not the state’s newly legalized recreational weed talking.
Maine, in all its blustery, soggy cold, can be a fantastic retreat, from its gorgeous winterscapes and outdoor to-do-ing (if you can’t beat ’em, join ’em) to destinations that pamper you with luxury.
These are merely the words of someone who just crashed at the iconic, recently reopened Cliff House , a nearly century-and-a-half-old resort (these days flying under the Destination Hotels banner) some 50 minutes’ drive south of Portland.
This particular hotel sits high atop bluffs above the Atlantic Ocean, a body of water that — trust me — gets particularly irritable come winter (the region’s most cyberbullied season). Her temperament only adds to the resort’s magnificent moxie.
And we lived to tell the tale. See how.
WHY NOW? Toast Cliff House’s year-round “reimagining.” Cliff House Because US Sen. Susan Collins told you to!
The state’s maverick Republican stopped by the 132-room hotel (more rooms to come), closed since October 2015 for massive renovations and opened last summer, to audaciously anoint it a “reimagined” year-round destination. (Cliff House used to close for the season.)
Other reasons aiding and abetting the cause include the hotel’s great big pile of indoor/outdoor newness including a luxury spa and wellness center, oceanfront dining and bars, redesigned rooms and a dramatic cliffside ballroom.
“Indigenous” landscaping, to boot!
The fact that devastating climate change decided to gift us with a psychotically warm and balmy winter this go-round, doesn’t hurt either (yet).
WORKING WELL The sea was angry that weekend, my friends.
Thrashing and roaring and frothing at the mouth, she wanted me dead, and she was mere feet away.
But I just sat in the property’s new spa’s sun lounge sanctuary in my white robe, holding a cup of herbal tea, just mocking and laughing at her hissy-fitting through giant, reinforced windows.
Watching these violent Atlantic waves, this aquatic pugilism in motion, is better than MMA, any day — it’s like a personal showing of “A Perfect Storm” on a giant UHDTV but, you know, better.
MUST-TRY There’s a hot tub here somewhere, see if you can spot it. Cliff House It’s the most beautiful compound noun in the English language: hot tub. And Cliff House has a seductive, new indoor one waiting for your dunking (there’s a pool, too, if you must). But the real treat is the large outdoor tub where it provides a steamy zone of invincibility when those mean, scary storms roll in overhead.
Feel free to tell those rumbling clouds, “Cash me outside!”
GET ACTIVE It’s counterintuitive, but those who live in Maine know your winter only improves if you go outdoors and get the adrenaline pumping. Try sledding on Cliff House’s knoll, moonlight snowshoeing, snowmobiling in nearby Sanford (the hotel’s rec team is especially of help here) or the hotel’s glow-in-the-dark mini golf, for starters.
You can also take a beer trek along Maine’s coast with David D’Auteuil’s Best Brew Tours (he drives, you don’t) or catch a performance of “Million Dollar Quartet” at the Ogunquit Playhouse.
And if you get there fast, you can take advantage of the state’s Restaurant Week , running through Sunday.
Tons of peeps at the beach, fresh local spirits, beer and food…a local guide who lives and works here @gatewaytomaine @ogunquitmaine @ogunquitwelcomesyou @york_maine @yorkvillagemaine @unionbluff our group today enjoyed @wigglybridgedistillery @somebrewingco @bearairishbrew 
A post shared by Best Brew Tours (@bestbrewtours) on Jul 3, 2016 at 2:30pm PDT 
Given the time of year (although if this winter is a guide, who even knows anymore?), there’s a chance a nor’easter will rain on your parade, so luckily there’s plenty of indoor hijinks to be had at Cliff House, as well (its Web site even has an entire page devoted to storm days). Enjoy vintage arcade and pinball games at its Nubb’s Lobster Shack restaurant, pool tables, a “beer bash” tasting on March 17, bingo, gingerbread house making/eating … and that hot tub and spa, duh!
NEEDS WORK When a storm rolls in, take cover under the sheets of your oceanfront king. Cliff House Remember, this is still Maine. It gets really cold and it gets really rainy — and there are sections of the hotel where you have to briefly walk outside in order to move between them (room to lobby, e.g.) where you’ll experience the forecast, first-hand.
The staff has a secret network of hallways that provide 100 percent indoor cover throughout, but unless your bribe game is on point, you won’t be using it.
BOTTOM LINE Is Maine the new Florida for winter vacations? No, stop being weird. However, this place is making a helluva go at it.
DETAILS The “Wicked Winter Escape” promo starts at $199 per night until April 30; DestinationHotels.com
